On the Connection Between Non-negative Matrix Factorization and Latent Dirichlet Allocation

Benedikt Geiger
Harvard University
benedikt_geiger@hms.harvard.edu
&Peter J. Park
Harvard University
peter_park@hms.harvard.edu
Abstract

Non-negative matrix factorization with the generalized Kullbackâ€“Leibler divergence (NMF) and latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) are two popular approaches for dimensionality reduction of non-negative data. Here, we show that NMF with â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraints on the columns of both matrices of the decomposition and a Dirichlet prior on the columns of one matrix is equivalent to LDA. To show this, we demonstrate that explicitly accounting for the scaling ambiguity of NMF by adding â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraints to the optimization problem allows a joint update of both matrices in the widely used multiplicative updates (MU) algorithm. When both of the matrices are normalized, the joint MU algorithm leads to probabilistic latent semantic analysis (PLSA), which is LDA without a Dirichlet prior. Our approach of deriving joint updates for NMF also reveals that a Lasso penalty on one matrix together with an â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraint on the other matrix is insufficient to induce any sparsity.

1 Introduction

Non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) and latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) are two prominent techniques for unsupervised machine learning and data analysis. Both approaches decompose non-negative data into an interpretable parts-based representation and have been used successfully across a wide range of areas including topic modeling, image and audio signal processing, recommendation systems, and bioinformatics [24, 46, 17]. However, despite their conceptual similarities and widespread use, the relationship between NMF and LDA remains underexplored. Although partial results exist, prior work is written from a probabilistic perspective, and empirical comparisons often fall short to appreciate the depth of their connection.

Non-negative matrix factorization Xâ‰ˆWâ¢Hğ‘‹ğ‘Šğ»X\approx WHitalic_X â‰ˆ italic_W italic_H with an appropriately chosen loss function is commonly viewed as a constrained optimization problem, with linear algebra algorithms employed to solve it. In the case of the widely used Kullbackâ€“Leibler (KL) divergence loss, the most popular approach for solving the optimization problem is the so-called multiplicative updates approach [17]. Originally derived by Richardson [39] and Lucy [31] in the context of deconvolution, it was rediscovered and applied to NMF in the seminal work of Lee and Seung [28, 27]. The algorithm alternates between updating each of the matrices Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H of the factorization in a multiplicative manner. Latent Dirichlet allocation was introduced as a generative statistical model of text data to learn the underlying topics, topic proportions of documents, and probabilistic topic assignments of individual words [4]. As a bag-of-words model, LDA assumes that the order of the words in each document does not play a role, and only the word-document count matrix Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X of a corpus is used during training and inference. The generative process of LDA extends that of its predecessor probabilistic latent semantic analysis (PLSA) [23, 22] by adding a Dirichlet prior to the topic proportions. Thus, a solution of PLSA can also be interpreted as a maximum a posteriori estimate of LDA under a uniform Dirichlet prior [18].

In addition to these connections to LDA, PLSA is well-known to be closely related to NMF. For normalized inputs Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, fixed points of the PLSA algorithm can be mapped to fixed points of the MU algorithm of NMF with the KL divergence, and vice versa [16]. The identical result has also been shown for global maxima of the PLSA likelihood and global minima of the KL loss of NMF [12]. Noticing similarities between the update rules and underlying generative processes of NMF, PLSA, and LDA dates back to earlier work on unified frameworks for probabilistic matrix decomposition [5, 6]. Various probabilistic latent variable models with joint parameter updates closely resembling the update rules of NMF have also been studied in [41, 42, 47]. However, an important detail frequently overlooked in the literature is that PLSA jointly updates the topic and topic proportion matrices, whereas the MU algorithm of NMF sequentially updates one matrix given the other.

In this paper, we reveal a deeper connection between NMF and topic models like PLSA and LDA. We solve NMF with additional normalization constraints, and show that this leads to algorithms resembling or identical to the PLSA algorithm. Our main contributions are the following:

  1. 1.

    For NMF with the KL divergence, adding normalization constraints to the columns of one or both matrices of the decomposition makes it possible to derive joint update rules for both matrices. The obtained algorithms save one matrix multiplication per iteration.

  2. 2.

    NMF with the KL divergence and additional normalization constraints on the columns of both matrices is equivalent to PLSA. Both the objective function and the canonical joint update rules are identical. In contrast to the existing literature, we establish an algorithmic equivalence, and our result neither requires normalizing the input matrix Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X nor transforming the trained model parameters.

  3. 3.

    With a Dirichlet prior on the columns of the matrix corresponding to the topic proportions, NMF with the KL divergence and additional normalization constraints on the columns of both matrices is equivalent to LDA. Both the objective function and the canonical variational inference algorithm are identical.

  4. 4.

    Joint update equations can be derived to speed up and better understand variations of NMF. We demonstrate this by revisiting sparse NMF with the KL divergence [30].

Joint update rules for NMF have recently been introduced in the more general case of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-divergence loss functions [33]. Both in [33] and in our work, the results are based on a majorization-minimization scheme in which an upper bound of the objective function is constructed and minimized in every iteration [43]. The approach differs from previous work by jointly considering both matrices of the decomposition instead of constructing an upper bound for one of the two matrices at a time [15, 36]. In contrast to [33], however, the additional normalizations allow us to derive a closed-form expression for the optimum of the upper bound.

That NMF with Dirichlet priors on the columns of both matrices of the decomposition leads to LDA with Dirichlet smoothing on the topics was briefly mentioned in [49, 48] and suggested in [9, Section 3.5]. By revisiting the connection between PLSA and NMF, our perspective emphasizes the role of the normalization constraints rather than the Dirichlet distribution giving rise to the connections between generative models and algorithms.

2 Related work

Bayesian NMF.

Non-negative matrix factorization can often be interpreted in a statistical framework [14]. For example, minimizing the KL divergence between the data matrix Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and its reconstruction Wâ¢Hğ‘Šğ»WHitalic_W italic_H is equivalent to maximizing the likelihood of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H in an element-wise Poisson noise model Xâˆ¼Poissonâ¡(Wâ¢H)similar-toğ‘‹Poissonğ‘Šğ»X\sim\operatorname{Poisson}(WH)italic_X âˆ¼ roman_Poisson ( italic_W italic_H ). Similar connections between the loss function and the likelihood of an appropriately chosen generative model also exist for alternative reconstruction errors [44]. In other words, the probabilistic point of view on NMF is based on the underlying statistical assumptions of the chosen reconstruction error. Through priors on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W or Hğ»Hitalic_H, this statistical framework allows one to induce desired properties of the factorization. Bayesian extensions of NMF have, for instance, been applied to control the sparsity or smoothness of the parameters [8, 45, 13], automatically select the factorization rank [44, 21], obtain uncertainty estimates [40], or model bounded support data [32].

In the case of NMF with the KL divergence, the most commonly used prior is the Gamma distribution [7, 45, 8, 14, 11, 35, 37]. The main reason for this choice is the analytical convenience resulting from the Gamma distribution being the conjugate prior of the Poisson distribution. The obtained Gammaâ€“Poisson model with fixed prior parameters has been shown to be related to LDA: When Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is column-normalized and Gamma priors with identical rate parameters are placed on the columns of Hğ»Hitalic_H, the generative model extends LDA by also modeling the document length [6, Lemma 1]. In fact, we strengthen this connection and prove that the canonical variational inference algorithm of this Gammaâ€“Poisson model is identical to the LDA algorithm from [4] (see AppendixÂ E). This algorithmic equivalence can be understood as the Bayesian counterpart to the connection between NMF with a normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and PLSA.

3 Preliminaries

Throughout the paper, our terminology draws inspiration from the topic modeling literature. That is, when considering the non-negative matrix decomposition Xâ‰ˆWâ¢Hğ‘‹ğ‘Šğ»X\approx WHitalic_X â‰ˆ italic_W italic_H, we use the terms (unnormalized) topic matrix to refer to Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and topic weights to refer to Hğ»Hitalic_H. When additional normalization constraints are in place, we use (normalized) topic matrix and topic proportions instead. We use the notation â„+subscriptâ„\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to refer to the non-negative real numbers, and for any positive integer Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, we denote the Mâˆ’1ğ‘€1M-1italic_M - 1 dimensional standard simplex by Î”Mâˆ’1={yâˆˆâ„+M|âˆ‘mym=1}subscriptÎ”ğ‘€1conditional-setğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘€subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘š1\Delta_{M-1}=\{y\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{M}\,|\,\sum_{m}y_{m}=1\}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_y âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 }. When using the abbreviation NMF, we refer to non-negative matrix factorization with the KL divergence unless noted otherwise.

In the context of topic modelling, the goal of NMF, PLSA, and LDA is to identify the underlying topics in a corpus of documents and to represent each document as an additive combination of the learned topics. All three methods are bag-of-words modelsâ€”they assume that learning the decomposition does not require taking the order of words in the documents into account. Therefore, the input of the algorithms is the term-document matrix Xâˆˆâ„+VÃ—Dğ‘‹subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‰ğ·X\in\mathbb{R}^{V\times D}_{+}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where each entry xvâ¢dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘x_{vd}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of times the term vğ‘£vitalic_v occurs in document dğ‘‘ditalic_d. The number of topics Kğ¾Kitalic_K is a hyperparameter of all three approaches.

3.1 Non-negative matrix factorization (NMF)

NMF decomposes the term-document matrix Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X into two non-negative matrices Wâˆˆâ„+VÃ—Kğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘‰ğ¾W\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{V\times K}italic_W âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V Ã— italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Hâˆˆâ„+KÃ—Dğ»superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ¾ğ·H\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{K\times D}italic_H âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The columns of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H can then be interpreted as the unnormalized topics and topic weights of the documents, respectively, and these parameters are learned by minimizing an appropriate â€œdistanceâ€œ D(X||WH)D(X\,||\,WH)italic_D ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) between the data matrix and its reconstruction. A common choice is the (generalized) Kullbackâ€“Leibler divergence

DKL(X||WH)=âˆ‘v,dxvâ¢dlogxvâ¢d(Wâ¢H)vâ¢dâˆ’xvâ¢d+(WH)vâ¢d,\displaystyle D_{\text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH)=\sum_{v,d}x_{vd}\log\frac{x_{vd}}{(WH)_% {vd}}-x_{vd}+(WH)_{vd},italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (1)

which leads to the optimization problem

minWâˆˆâ„+VÃ—K,Hâˆˆâ„+KÃ—DDKL(X||WH).\displaystyle\min_{W\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{V\times K},\,H\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{K% \times D}}D_{\text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH).roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V Ã— italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) . (2)

Algorithms to solve (2) typically alternate between updating each of the matrices Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H while fixing the other one [19]. The motivation for this approach is two-fold [17]. First, the factorization Xâ‰ˆWâ¢Hğ‘‹ğ‘Šğ»X\approx WHitalic_X â‰ˆ italic_W italic_H is symmetric to XTâ‰ˆHTâ¢WTsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡superscriptğ»ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡X^{T}\approx H^{T}W^{T}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. An update rule for one of the matrices thus immediately yields an update rule for the other. Second, the optimization problems induced by fixing each of the two matrices in (2) are convex. The most common algorithm consists of multiplicatively updating each matrix iteratively until convergence (see AlgorithmÂ 1). It was popularized by Lee and Seung, who demonstrated the potential of learning parts-based representations and proved the monotonic convergence of the objective function [27, 28, 46]. The key idea of their derivation is to construct a well-behaved function Gâ¢(H,Hâ€²)ğºğ»superscriptğ»â€²G(H,H^{\prime})italic_G ( italic_H , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for F(H)=DKL(X||WH)F(H)=D_{\text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH)italic_F ( italic_H ) = italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) such that

Gâ¢(H,Hâ€²)â‰¥Fâ¢(H)for allÂ â¢H,Hâ€²,Gâ¢(Hâ€²,Hâ€²)=Fâ¢(Hâ€²)for allÂ â¢Hâ€².formulae-sequenceğºğ»superscriptğ»â€²ğ¹ğ»for allÂ ğ»superscriptğ»â€²ğºsuperscriptğ»â€²superscriptğ»â€²ğ¹superscriptğ»â€²for allÂ superscriptğ»â€²\begin{split}G(H,H^{\prime})&\geq F(H)\quad\text{for all }H,\,H^{\prime},\\ G(H^{\prime},H^{\prime})&=F(H^{\prime})\quad\text{for all }H^{\prime}.\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL italic_G ( italic_H , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL â‰¥ italic_F ( italic_H ) for all italic_H , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_G ( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL = italic_F ( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for all italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (3)

Once such an auxiliary function GğºGitalic_G is found, the objective function Fğ¹Fitalic_F can be shown to be non-increasing by updating an iterate H(n)superscriptğ»ğ‘›H^{(n)}italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the argument of the minimum of Hâ†¦Gâ¢(H,H(n))maps-toğ»ğºğ»superscriptğ»ğ‘›H\mapsto G(H,H^{(n)})italic_H â†¦ italic_G ( italic_H , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (see AppendixÂ A). While the perspective on (1) and the construction of the auxiliary function in [28] via Jensenâ€™s inequality is entirely non-probabilistic, there is also a probabilistic framework for AlgorithmÂ 1 [8, 14]. Assuming conditional independence of the counts Xvâ¢dsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£ğ‘‘X_{vd}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the model Xvâ¢dâˆ¼Poisson(WH)vâ¢dX_{vd}\sim\operatorname{Poisson}(WH)_{vd}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ roman_Poisson ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT leads to a log-likelihood identical to the negative KL divergence (1) (up to a constant). a standard expectation-maximization (EM) [10] procedure yields a joint auxiliary function GğºGitalic_G for the model parameters (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ), i.e.,

With

Ï•vâ¢kâ¢d(n)â‰”wvâ¢k(n)â¢hkâ¢d(n)(W(n)â¢H(n))vâ¢dâ‰”superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›ğ‘£ğ‘‘\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}\coloneqq\frac{w_{vk}^{(n)}h_{kd}^{(n)}}{(W^{(n)}H^{(n)})_{vd}}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG (6)

and modulo terms independent of the model parameters, the auxiliary function is given by

cf.Â [8, eq.Â (18)]. Although a closed-form joint optimum does not exist, GğºGitalic_G induces auxiliary functions for both individual matrices via

G~â¢(W,W(n))=Gâ¢((W,H(n)),(W(n),H(n))),G~â¢(H,H(n))=Gâ¢((W(n),H),(W(n),H(n))).formulae-sequence~ğºğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘›ğºğ‘Šsuperscriptğ»ğ‘›superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›~ğºğ»superscriptğ»ğ‘›ğºsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘›ğ»superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›\begin{split}\widetilde{G}(W,W^{(n)})&=G((W,H^{(n)}),(W^{(n)},H^{(n)})),\\ \widetilde{G}(H,H^{(n)})&=G((W^{(n)},H),(W^{(n)},H^{(n)})).\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG ( italic_W , italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL = italic_G ( ( italic_W , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG ( italic_H , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL = italic_G ( ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) , ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) . end_CELL end_ROW (8)

Alternating between optimizing each of the induced auxiliary functions recovers the multiplicative updates from Lee and Seung, revealing that AlgorithmÂ 1 is in fact a generalized EM algorithm.

In practice, it is often desirable to increase the interpretability of the matrices and to eliminate the scaling ambiguity of the factorization caused by Wâ¢H=Wâ¢Dâ¢Dâˆ’1â¢Hğ‘Šğ»ğ‘Šğ·superscriptğ·1ğ»WH=WDD^{-1}Hitalic_W italic_H = italic_W italic_D italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H for any invertible diagonal matrix Dâˆˆâ„+KÃ—Kğ·subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ¾ğ¾D\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times K}_{+}italic_D âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K Ã— italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A common strategy to achieve both is to normalize the columns of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W to probability distributions and to scale the rows of Hğ»Hitalic_H accordingly after each iteration or after convergence.

3.2 Probabilistic latent semantic analysis (PLSA)

In PLSA [23], the generative process of the term-document matrix is unfolded in the sense that the words are generated individually. The scheme for each of the n=1,â€¦,Ndğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘n=1,\ldots,N_{d}italic_n = 1 , â€¦ , italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT words in document dğ‘‘ditalic_d is the following:

  1. 1.

    Sample a latent topic znâ¢dsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘z_{nd}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability pâ¢(znâ¢d=k)=hkâ¢dğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘p(z_{nd}=k)=h_{kd}italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ) = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Sample a word Î½nâ¢dsubscriptğœˆğ‘›ğ‘‘\nu_{nd}italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability pâ¢(Î½nâ¢d=v|znâ¢d=k)=wvâ¢kğ‘subscriptğœˆğ‘›ğ‘‘conditionalğ‘£subscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜p(\nu_{nd}=v|z_{nd}=k)=w_{vk}italic_p ( italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The resulting log-likelihood is given by

logp(X|W,H)=âˆ‘v,dxvâ¢dlog(WH)vâ¢d+c(X),\log p(X|W,H)=\sum_{v,d}x_{vd}\log(WH)_{vd}+c(X),roman_log italic_p ( italic_X | italic_W , italic_H ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ( italic_X ) , (9)

where the constant câ¢(X)ğ‘ğ‘‹c(X)italic_c ( italic_X ) arises from bagging the sequence of words, cf.Â [6, Section III.A]. In the following, we will always ignore this constant because it only depends on the observed counts and does not affect model training. The relevant part of the log-likelihood (9) therefore reduces to

â„’PLSA(X|W,H)â‰”âˆ‘v,dxvâ¢dlog(WH)vâ¢d.\mathcal{L}^{\text{PLSA}}(X|W,H)\coloneqq\sum_{v,d}x_{vd}\log(WH)_{vd}.caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PLSA end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X | italic_W , italic_H ) â‰” âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (10)

The algorithm to fit the model parameters is an EM algorithm, described in [23]. With the conditional distributions of the latent topic assignments for model parameters (W(n),H(n))superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›(W^{(n)},H^{(n)})( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) equal to

pâ¢(znâ¢d=k|Î½nâ¢d=v)(n)=Ï•vâ¢kâ¢d(n)âˆwvâ¢k(n)â¢hkâ¢d(n),ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘conditionalğ‘˜subscriptğœˆğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›proportional-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›\displaystyle p(z_{nd}=k|\nu_{nd}=v)^{(n)}=\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}\propto w_{vk}^{(n)% }h_{kd}^{(n)},italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k | italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (11)

the E-step of the derivation naturally leads to an auxiliary function of the negative objective function (10) given by

Gâ¢((W,H),(W(n),H(n)))=âˆ’âˆ‘v,k,dxvâ¢dâ¢Ï•vâ¢kâ¢d(n)â¢logâ¡wvâ¢kâ¢hkâ¢dÏ•vâ¢kâ¢d(n).ğºğ‘Šğ»superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›G((W,H),(W^{(n)},H^{(n)}))=-\sum_{v,k,d}x_{vd}\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}\log\frac{w_{vk}% h_{kd}}{\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}}.italic_G ( ( italic_W , italic_H ) , ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_k , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (12)

The minimization of GğºGitalic_G during the M-step yields AlgorithmÂ 2. While the algorithm is remarkably similar to AlgorithmÂ 1 and the only difference seems to be the normalizations, it is important to note that all model parameters are updated jointly in PLSA. The conditional distributions of the topic assignments Ï•vâ¢kâ¢dsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\phi_{vkd}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not recomputed after updating one of the matrices.

3.3 Latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA)

LDA was developed to overcome the issue that the number of model parameters of PLSA grows linearly with the number of documents on which the model is trained [4, 3]. To this end, LDA introduces a model parameter Î±âˆˆâ„>0Kğ›¼subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ¾absent0\alpha\in\mathbb{R}^{K}_{>0}italic_Î± âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a Dirichlet prior hâˆ¼Dirâ¡(Î±)similar-toâ„Dirğ›¼h\sim\operatorname{Dir}(\alpha)italic_h âˆ¼ roman_Dir ( italic_Î± ) that turn the topic proportions into latent variables. The generative process for each document dğ‘‘ditalic_d then becomes

  1. 1.

    Sample the topic proportions hdâˆ¼Dirâ¡(Î±).similar-tosubscriptâ„ğ‘‘Dirğ›¼h_{d}\sim\operatorname{Dir}(\alpha).italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ roman_Dir ( italic_Î± ) .

  2. 2.

    For each of the n=1,â€¦,Ndğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘n=1,\ldots,N_{d}italic_n = 1 , â€¦ , italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT words in document dğ‘‘ditalic_d:

    1. (a)

      Sample a latent topic znâ¢dsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘z_{nd}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability pâ¢(znâ¢d=k)=hkâ¢dğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘p(z_{nd}=k)=h_{kd}italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ) = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

    2. (b)

      Sample a word Î½nâ¢dsubscriptğœˆğ‘›ğ‘‘\nu_{nd}italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability pâ¢(Î½nâ¢d=v|znâ¢d=k)=wvâ¢kğ‘subscriptğœˆğ‘›ğ‘‘conditionalğ‘£subscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜p(\nu_{nd}=v|z_{nd}=k)=w_{vk}italic_p ( italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

This results in the log-likelihood

logâ¡pâ¢(xd|W,Î±)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘Šğ›¼\displaystyle\log p(x_{d}|W,\alpha)roman_log italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_W , italic_Î± ) =logâ¢âˆ«pâ¢(h|Î±)â¢âˆv(Wâ¢h)vxvâ¢dâ¢dâ¢h,absentğ‘conditionalâ„ğ›¼subscriptproductğ‘£superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šâ„ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘â„\displaystyle=\log\int p(h|\alpha)\prod_{v}(Wh)_{v}^{x_{vd}}\,dh,= roman_log âˆ« italic_p ( italic_h | italic_Î± ) âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W italic_h ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_h , (13)

where pâ¢(h|Î±)ğ‘conditionalâ„ğ›¼p(h|\alpha)italic_p ( italic_h | italic_Î± ) denotes the density of the Dirichlet distribution. The introduction of the Dirichlet prior causes the posterior distribution of the latent variables (hd,zd)subscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘(h_{d},z_{d})( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to be intractable. Blei et al.Â therefore resort to variational inference (VI), which is one of the approximate inference algorithms applicable to the LDA model [25, 4, 1]. Following their mean-field approach, the true posterior is approximated with a variational distribution qğ‘qitalic_q given by

qâ¢(h,z|Î²,Ï•)=âˆdqdâ¢(hd,zd|Î²d,Ï•d),qdâ¢(hd,zd|Î²d,Ï•d)=qâ¢(hd|Î²d)â¢âˆnqâ¢(znâ¢d|Ï•nâ¢d),formulae-sequenceğ‘â„conditionalğ‘§ğ›½italic-Ï•subscriptproductğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘‘ğ‘conditionalsubscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘subscriptproductğ‘›ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›ğ‘‘\displaystyle q(h,z|\beta,\phi)=\prod_{d}q_{d}(h_{d},z_{d}|\beta_{d},\phi_{d})% ,\qquad q_{d}(h_{d},z_{d}|\beta_{d},\phi_{d})=q(h_{d}|\beta_{d})\prod_{n}q(z_{% nd}|\phi_{nd}),italic_q ( italic_h , italic_z | italic_Î² , italic_Ï• ) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_q ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (14)

where Î²dsubscriptğ›½ğ‘‘\beta_{d}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•nâ¢dsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›ğ‘‘\phi_{nd}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are parameters of a Dirichlet and categorical distribution, respectively. In addition to the model parameters Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, these so-called variational parameters are iteratively optimized by the algorithm. Instead of maximizing the exact log-likelihood, the idea of variational inference is to optimize a lower bound given by

â„’LDAâ¢(X|W,Î±,Î²,Ï•)=ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡pâ¢(X,h,z|W,Î±)]âˆ’ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡qâ¢(h,z|Î²,Ï•)].superscriptâ„’LDAconditionalğ‘‹ğ‘Šğ›¼ğ›½italic-Ï•subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘‹â„conditionalğ‘§ğ‘Šğ›¼subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘â„conditionalğ‘§ğ›½italic-Ï•\mathcal{L}^{\text{LDA}}(X|W,\alpha,\beta,\phi)=\mathbb{E}_{q}\!\left[\log p(X% ,h,z|W,\alpha)\right]-\mathbb{E}_{q}\!\left[\log q(h,z|\beta,\phi)\right].caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT LDA end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X | italic_W , italic_Î± , italic_Î² , italic_Ï• ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( italic_X , italic_h , italic_z | italic_W , italic_Î± ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_h , italic_z | italic_Î² , italic_Ï• ) ] . (15)

Here and in the following, ğ”¼qâ¢[â‹…]subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]â‹…\mathbb{E}_{q}\!\left[\cdot\right]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ â‹… ] denotes the expectation with respect to the variational distribution. Similar to PLSA, the key insight that reveals algebraic connections to NMF is that the optimal variational approximation of the posterior of the topic assignments znâ¢dsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘‘z_{nd}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not depend on the position nğ‘›nitalic_n, but only on the word Î½nâ¢dsubscriptğœˆğ‘›ğ‘‘\nu_{nd}italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at position nğ‘›nitalic_n, i.e., Ï•nâ¢dsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›ğ‘‘\phi_{nd}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be reindexed. Together with

h~kâ¢dâ¢(Î²d)â‰”expâ¡(ğ”¼qâ¢(hd|Î²d)â¢[logâ¡hkâ¢d]),â‰”subscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘subscriptğ”¼ğ‘conditionalsubscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘delimited-[]subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\widetilde{h}_{kd}(\beta_{d})\coloneqq\exp\big{(}\mathbb{E}_{q(h_{d}|\beta_{d}% )}[\log h_{kd}]\big{)},over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰” roman_exp ( blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) , (16)

which can be computed explicitly using the digamma function, the variational lower bound (15) reduces to

â„’LDAâ¢(X|W,Î±,Î²,Ï•)=âˆ‘v,k,dxvâ¢dâ¢Ï•vâ¢kâ¢dâ¢logâ¡wvâ¢kâ¢h~kâ¢dÏ•vâ¢kâ¢d+âˆ‘d(logâ¡Î“â¢(âˆ‘kÎ±k)âˆ’logâ¡Î“â¢(âˆ‘kÎ²kâ¢d))+âˆ‘k,d(logâ¡Î“â¢(Î²kâ¢d)âˆ’logâ¡Î“â¢(Î±k)+(Î±kâˆ’Î²kâ¢d)â¢ğ”¼qâ¢[logâ¡hkâ¢d]),superscriptâ„’LDAconditionalğ‘‹ğ‘Šğ›¼ğ›½italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘Î“subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜Î“subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘‘Î“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘‘Î“subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\displaystyle\begin{split}\mathcal{L}^{\text{LDA}}(X|W,\alpha,\beta,\phi)&=% \sum_{v,k,d}x_{vd}\phi_{vkd}\log\frac{w_{vk}\widetilde{h}_{kd}}{\phi_{vkd}}+% \sum_{d}\Big{(}\log\Gamma(\textstyle{\sum}_{k}\alpha_{k})-\log\Gamma(% \textstyle{\sum}_{k}\beta_{kd})\Big{)}\\ &\phantom{=}+\displaystyle\sum_{k,d}\Big{(}\log\Gamma(\beta_{kd})-\log\Gamma(% \alpha_{k})+(\alpha_{k}-\beta_{kd})\mathbb{E}_{q}\!\left[\log h_{kd}\right]% \Big{)},\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT LDA end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X | italic_W , italic_Î± , italic_Î² , italic_Ï• ) end_CELL start_CELL = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_k , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_log roman_Î“ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log roman_Î“ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_log roman_Î“ ( italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log roman_Î“ ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) , end_CELL end_ROW (17)

cf.Â [4, A.1, eq.Â (15), (16)]. The VI algorithm is a variational EM procedure. It alternates between optimizing the approximation of the posterior distribution of the latent variables for fixed model parameters (variational E-step) and optimizing the model parameters for a fixed variational distribution (variational M-step). That is, (17) is optimized with respect to (Î²,Ï•)ğ›½italic-Ï•(\beta,\phi)( italic_Î² , italic_Ï• ) during the variational E-step and with respect to (W,Î±)ğ‘Šğ›¼(W,\alpha)( italic_W , italic_Î± ) during the variational M-step. Since there is no closed-form optimum for the parameter of the Dirichlet prior Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, we assume that it is fixed for simplicity. This procedure results in AlgorithmÂ 3.

4 Algorithms for NMF with normalization constraints

We now consider the NMF optimization problem (2) with additional normalization constraints on the topics or both the topics and the topic weights. We describe the connections between the original formulation and the sum-constrained optimization problems, and derive NMF algorithms with joint update rules. These new NMF algorithms are based on the observation that a constrained optimization of the joint auxiliary function (7) is possible.

More precisely, the two optimization problems we consider are NMF with normalized topics

minWâˆˆÎ”Vâˆ’1K,Hâˆˆâ„+KÃ—DDKL(X||WH),\displaystyle\min_{W\in\Delta_{V-1}^{K},\,H\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{K\times D}}D_{% \text{KL}}(X||WH),roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) , (18)

as well as NMF with both normalized topics and topic proportions

minWâˆˆÎ”Vâˆ’1K,HâˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1DDKL(X||WH).\displaystyle\min_{W\in\Delta_{V-1}^{K},\,H\in\Delta_{K-1}^{D}}D_{\text{KL}}(X% ||WH).roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) . (19)

At first glance, it might seem unnatural to normalize both matrices Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H without adjusting the input matrix Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X. However, with both constraints, we have âˆ‘v(Wâ¢H)vâ¢d=1subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘Šğ»ğ‘£ğ‘‘1\sum_{v}(WH)_{vd}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, and the objective function of (19) becomes

âˆ’âˆ‘v,dxvâ¢dlog(WH)vâ¢d=âˆ’âˆ‘d(âˆ‘vâ€²xvâ€²â¢d)âˆ‘vxvâ¢dâˆ‘vâ€²xvâ€²â¢dlog(Whd)v.-\sum_{v,d}x_{vd}\log(WH)_{vd}=-\sum_{d}\Big{(}\sum_{v^{\prime}}x_{v^{\prime}d% }\Big{)}\sum_{v}\frac{x_{vd}}{\sum_{v^{\prime}}x_{v^{\prime}d}}\log(Wh_{d})_{v}.- âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( italic_W italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (20)

The inner sum corresponds to the Kullbackâ€“Leibler divergence between the empirical distribution induced by the observed counts (xvâ¢d)vsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘£(x_{vd})_{v}( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the model distribution (Wâ¢hd)vsubscriptğ‘Šsubscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘£(Wh_{d})_{v}( italic_W italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [22, eq.Â (10)]. In particular, optimization problem (19) and PLSA have the same objective function. Both models project the samples onto the simplex spanned by the topics based on the KL divergence. The following lemmas clarify the connections between all three NMF problems with different normalization constraints.

Lemma 4.1.

Let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of the standard NMF optimization problem (2) and let Î»k=âˆ‘vwvâ¢ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜\lambda_{k}=\sum_{v}w_{vk}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then (W~,H~)~ğ‘Š~ğ»(\widetilde{W},\widetilde{H})( over~ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) with w~vâ¢k=wvâ¢k/Î»ksubscript~ğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\widetilde{w}_{vk}=w_{vk}/\lambda_{k}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and h~kâ¢d=Î»kâ¢hkâ¢dsubscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\widetilde{h}_{kd}=\lambda_{k}h_{kd}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a solution of NMF with a normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W (18). Conversely, every solution of (18) is a solution of (2).

Lemma 4.2.

Let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of NMF with a normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W (18) and let Î»d=âˆ‘vxvâ¢dsubscriptğœ†ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘\lambda_{d}=\sum_{v}x_{vd}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then (W,H~)ğ‘Š~ğ»(W,\widetilde{H})( italic_W , over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) with h~kâ¢d=hkâ¢d/Î»dsubscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘\widetilde{h}_{kd}=h_{kd}/\lambda_{d}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a solution of NMF with a normalization constraint on both Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H (19). Conversely, let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of (19). Then (W,H~)ğ‘Š~ğ»(W,\widetilde{H})( italic_W , over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) with h~kâ¢d=Î»dâ¢hkâ¢dsubscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\widetilde{h}_{kd}=\lambda_{d}h_{kd}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a solution of (18).

LemmaÂ 4.1 follows directly from Wâ¢H=Wâ¢Dâ¢Dâˆ’1â¢Hğ‘Šğ»ğ‘Šğ·superscriptğ·1ğ»WH=WDD^{-1}Hitalic_W italic_H = italic_W italic_D italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H for any invertible non-negative diagonal matrix Dğ·Ditalic_D and the proof of LemmaÂ 4.2 is deferred to AppendixÂ B. Taken together, these two results show that a solution of one of the three NMF problems (2), (18) or (19) can be readily converted into a solution of one of the other optimization problems. In fact, one can also see that an analogous result holds for the fixed points of their MU algorithms (see below).

Contrary to intuition, the additional normalization constraints simplify the NMF optimization problem. Recall that the joint auxiliary function (7) of DKL(X||WH)D_{\text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) is given by

Gâ¢((W,H),(W(n),H(n)))ğºğ‘Šğ»superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›\displaystyle G((W,H),(W^{(n)},H^{(n)}))italic_G ( ( italic_W , italic_H ) , ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) =âˆ’âˆ‘v,k,dxvâ¢dâ¢Ï•vâ¢kâ¢d(n)â¢logâ¡wvâ¢kâ¢hkâ¢dÏ•vâ¢kâ¢d(n)+âˆ‘v,d(Wâ¢H)vâ¢d.absentsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Šğ»ğ‘£ğ‘‘\displaystyle=-\sum_{v,k,d}x_{vd}\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}\log\frac{w_{vk}h_{kd}}{\phi_% {vkd}^{(n)}}+\sum_{v,d}(WH)_{vd}.= - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_k , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Under the constraints wkâˆˆÎ”Vâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptÎ”ğ‘‰1w_{k}\in\Delta_{V-1}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the second summand reduces to âˆ‘k,dhkâ¢dsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\sum_{k,d}h_{kd}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and GğºGitalic_G can be jointly optimized in all model parameters (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ). Using Lagrange multipliers, we obtain the joint multiplicative update equations given in AlgorithmÂ 4 (see AppendixÂ B for details). When additionally imposing hdâˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1subscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1h_{d}\in\Delta_{K-1}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the relevant summands of the auxiliary function are identical to the auxiliary function (12) of PLSA. Accordingly, the canonical multiplicative algorithm for (19) is the PLSA algorithm, cf.Â AlgorithmsÂ 6 andÂ 2. The two models are equivalent both in the sense that their optimization problems are the same and in the sense that their MU algorithms coincide.

Although it is also possible to derive update rules that alternate between updating Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H using the induced auxiliary functions (8), the joint update equations have one major advantage. They do not require Wâ¢Hğ‘Šğ»WHitalic_W italic_H to be recomputed after updating one of the two matrices, which reduces the number of matrix multiplication per iteration from four to three. From a theoretical perspective, the joint updates turn NMF from a generalized EM algorithm into an EM algorithm. Another interesting observation is that the generative process (4) of NMF does not explicitly model the latent topic assignments of individual words in documents. However, the correspondence to PLSA and its generative process shows that Ï•vâ¢kâ¢dsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\phi_{vkd}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is in fact the posterior probability that a word vğ‘£vitalic_v in document dğ‘‘ditalic_d has been generated by topic kğ‘˜kitalic_k. For given data Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, the two generative processes of NMF with normalization constraints and PLSA are equivalent and they reveal different perspectives on the factorization. On the one hand, the Poisson noise model of NMF is more concise and motivates to not store Ï•vâ¢kâ¢dsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\phi_{vkd}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT explicitly during model training. On the other hand, the atomic generative process of PLSA adds a layer of interpretability to the model parameters. More details on the connections between various generative models are given in AppendixÂ D, and we also refer the interested reader to [6].

5 Connection between NMF and LDA

The previous section revealed the equivalence of NMF with additional normalization constraints and PLSA. Since the only difference between PLSA and LDA is the Dirichlet prior on the topic proportions, it is natural to wonder whether NMF with normalization constraints and a Dirichlet prior on the columns of Hğ»Hitalic_H is equivalent to LDA. This turns out to be the case.

With the normalization constraints wkâˆˆÎ”Vâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptÎ”ğ‘‰1w_{k}\in\Delta_{V-1}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the topic matrix Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, the following Dirichletâ€“Poisson generative model yields, up to a data-dependent constant, the same log-likelihood and variational lower bound as LDA:

  1. 1.

    Sample the topic proportions hdâˆ¼Dirâ¡(Î±)similar-tosubscriptâ„ğ‘‘Dirğ›¼h_{d}\sim\operatorname{Dir}(\alpha)italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ roman_Dir ( italic_Î± ).

  2. 2.

    Sample the topic contributions zvâ¢kâ¢dâˆ¼Poissonâ¡(wvâ¢kâ¢hkâ¢d)similar-tosubscriptğ‘§ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘Poissonsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘z_{vkd}\sim\operatorname{Poisson}(w_{vk}h_{kd})italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ roman_Poisson ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  3. 3.

    Xvâ¢d=âˆ‘kzvâ¢kâ¢dsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘§ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘X_{vd}=\sum_{k}z_{vkd}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Denoting the slice z:â£:dsubscriptğ‘§::absentğ‘‘z_{::d}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT : : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the latent tensor zğ‘§zitalic_z as zdsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘z_{d}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the fiber zv:dsubscriptğ‘§:ğ‘£ğ‘‘z_{v:d}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as zvâ¢dsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘£ğ‘‘z_{vd}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we apply a mean-field variational inference approach and approximate the true posterior of the latent variables with a variational distribution given by

qâ¢(h,z|Î²,Ï•)=âˆdqdâ¢(hd,zd|Î²d,Ï•d),qdâ¢(hd,zd|Î²d,Ï•d)=qâ¢(hd|Î²d)â¢âˆvqâ¢(zvâ¢d|xvâ¢d,Ï•vâ¢d),formulae-sequenceğ‘â„conditionalğ‘§ğ›½italic-Ï•subscriptproductğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘‘ğ‘conditionalsubscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘subscriptproductğ‘£ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘‘\displaystyle q(h,z|\beta,\phi)=\prod_{d}q_{d}(h_{d},z_{d}|\beta_{d},\phi_{d})% ,\qquad q_{d}(h_{d},z_{d}|\beta_{d},\phi_{d})=q(h_{d}|\beta_{d})\prod_{v}q(z_{% vd}|x_{vd},\phi_{vd}),italic_q ( italic_h , italic_z | italic_Î² , italic_Ï• ) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_q ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (21)

where Î²dsubscriptğ›½ğ‘‘\beta_{d}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•vâ¢dsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘‘\phi_{vd}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are Dirichlet and multinomial parameters, respectively. With the joint likelihood of the observed and latent variables of a single document being equal to

pâ¢(xd,hd,zd|W,Î±)=(âˆvğŸ™âˆ‘kzvâ¢kâ¢d=xvâ¢d)â¢pâ¢(hd|Î±)â¢âˆv,kpâ¢(zvâ¢kâ¢d|W,hd),ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘ğ‘Šğ›¼subscriptproductğ‘£subscript1subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘§ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘conditionalsubscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ›¼subscriptproductğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘Šsubscriptâ„ğ‘‘p(x_{d},h_{d},z_{d}|W,\alpha)=\Big{(}\prod_{v}\mathbbm{1}_{\sum_{k}z_{vkd}=x_{% vd}}\Big{)}p(h_{d}|\alpha)\prod_{v,k}p(z_{vkd}|W,h_{d}),italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_W , italic_Î± ) = ( âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î± ) âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_W , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (22)

the relevant terms of the variational lower bound of the Dirichletâ€“Poisson model with normalized topic matrix Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W are identical to the variational lower bound (17) of LDA, and the VI algorithms are identical too (see AppendixÂ C). Similar to the connection between NMF with normalization constraints and PLSA, the two different generative processes reveal different perspectives on the factorization. On the one hand, the Dirichletâ€“Poisson model of NMF is more concice and motivates to not store the variational parameters Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• explicitly during model trainingâ€”a computational trick that is already used in efficient LDA implementations [20, 38], cf.Â AlgorithmsÂ 5 andÂ 3. On the other hand, the multinomial generative process of LDA adds a layer of interpretability to Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•.

6 Sparse NMF

In sparse NMF, a penalty on Hğ»Hitalic_H is added to decrease the number of topics used in the reconstruction of each document. This is especially useful when the number of topics is high, as it can prevent overfitting and improve the interpretability of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W [26]. For a hyperparameter Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0, the objective function of â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-penalized NMF is given by

DKL(X||WH)+Î»âˆ¥Hâˆ¥1.D_{\text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH)+\lambda\|H\|_{1}.italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) + italic_Î» âˆ¥ italic_H âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (23)

An important technical difficulty of sparse NMF is that the scaling ambiguity of the matrix product Wâ¢Hğ‘Šğ»WHitalic_W italic_H in combination with a penalty on Hğ»Hitalic_H would cause Hğ»Hitalic_H to converge to zero and Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W to blow up unless further constraints are imposed. For this reason, the columns of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W are usually required to be normalized, and the optimization problem becomes

minWâˆˆÎ”Vâˆ’1K,Hâˆˆâ„+KÃ—DDKL(X||WH)+Î»âˆ¥Hâˆ¥1.\displaystyle\min_{W\in\Delta_{V-1}^{K},\,H\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{K\times D}}D_{% \text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH)+\lambda\|H\|_{1}.roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) + italic_Î» âˆ¥ italic_H âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (24)

With the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraints on the columns of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W in place, the results from SectionÂ 4 can be readily applied to obtain joint update rules to solve (24). Similar to before, the objective function value can be shown to be non-increasing under the following joint updates:

wvâ¢k(n+1)âˆwvâ¢k(n)â¢âˆ‘dxvâ¢dâ¢hkâ¢d(n)(W(n)â¢H(n))vâ¢d,hkâ¢d(n+1)=11+Î»â¢hkâ¢d(n)â¢âˆ‘vxvâ¢dâ¢wvâ¢k(n)(W(n)â¢H(n))vâ¢d.formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›1ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›1ğ‘˜ğ‘‘11ğœ†subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›ğ‘£ğ‘‘\displaystyle w^{(n+1)}_{vk}\propto w^{(n)}_{vk}\sum_{d}x_{vd}\frac{h^{(n)}_{% kd}}{(W^{(n)}H^{(n)})_{vd}},\qquad h^{(n+1)}_{kd}=\frac{1}{1+\lambda}h^{(n)}_{% kd}\sum_{v}x_{vd}\frac{w^{(n)}_{vk}}{(W^{(n)}H^{(n)})_{vd}}.italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Î» end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (25)

The only difference between â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-penalized NMF and NMF without a penalty (18) is that the topic weights Hğ»Hitalic_H are scaled by a factor of 11+Î»11ğœ†\frac{1}{1+\lambda}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Î» end_ARG, cf.Â AlgorithmÂ 4. Surprisingly, however, this holds true not only for the first, but for every iteration of the algorithm. Our observation is not a consequence of the algorithmic approach, but a property of the optimization problem itself:

Lemma 6.1.

Let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of NMF with an â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W (18) and let Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0. Then (W,11+Î»â¢H)ğ‘Š11ğœ†ğ»(W,\tfrac{1}{1+\lambda}H)( italic_W , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Î» end_ARG italic_H ) is a solution of Lasso-penalized NMF with an â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraint (24). Conversely, let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of (24). Then (W,(1+Î»)â¢H)ğ‘Š1ğœ†ğ»(W,(1+\lambda)H)( italic_W , ( 1 + italic_Î» ) italic_H ) is a solution of (18).

A proof by contradiction is provided in AppendixÂ F. The Lasso penalty being insufficient to induce sparse topic weights Hğ»Hitalic_H has, to the best of our knowledge, not been reported in the literature [34]. Interestingly, however, replacing the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraints on the columns of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W with â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT normalization constraints and using the heuristic gradient-based algorithm from [26] leads to sparsity [29, Section IV]. In fact, any normalization constraints on the columns of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and penalty terms on Hğ»Hitalic_H can be proven to act as competing regularizers on the two matrices (see AppendixÂ F). Together with LemmaÂ 6.1, this demonstrates that the effect on the sparsity of the model parameters not only depends on the penalty on Hğ»Hitalic_H, but also on the choice of the normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and the reconstruction error.

7 Conclusion

This paper has examined NMF with normalization constraints on the columns of one or both matrices of the decomposition. By taking these constraints into account explicitly during the majorization-minimization scheme, it became possible to derive joint update rules that speed up model training significantly. The joint update rules further bridge the gap between NMF optimization problems and algorithms from the topic modeling literature such as PLSA and LDA. Leveraging these connections, we have demonstrated that different latent structures of equivalent generative models can highlight complementary aspects of the same model.

The existing theoretical and applied research on other aspects and extensions of NMF or LDA is beyond the scope of our work. However, we anticipate that the outlined connections are not limited to the classical full-batch variational inference algorithms of these base models. Regarding NMF, directly resolving the scaling ambiguity in the case of the Kullbackâ€“Leibler divergence allowed us to re-examine the Lasso penalty for sparse NMF and might also be helpful in answering questions on the convergence of the model parameters [2]. An interesting but ambitious direction would be to extend these ideas to more general loss functions.

Acknowledgments

This work was funded by the National Institutes of Health (grant number R01CA269805). All authors declare no conflict of interest.

We would like to express our gratitude to Marinka Zitnik for her advice throughout the project. Moreover, we thank Christian Fiedler, Teng Gao, Allen Lynch, and Dominik Glodzik for their helpful feedback on the manuscript.

Appendix A Auxiliary functions for NMF

We give a brief overview of the fundamental idea of majorization-minimization algorithms and the construction of auxiliary functions for NMF with the KL divergence. This section is based on [43, 28, 17].

Consider the optimization problem

minYâˆˆğ’´â¡Fâ¢(Y)subscriptğ‘Œğ’´ğ¹ğ‘Œ\min_{Y\in\mathcal{Y}}F(Y)roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y âˆˆ caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Y )

for ğ’´âŠ†â„Mğ’´superscriptâ„ğ‘€\mathcal{Y}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{M}caligraphic_Y âŠ† blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a function F:ğ’´â†’â„.:ğ¹â†’ğ’´â„F\colon\mathcal{Y}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}.italic_F : caligraphic_Y â†’ blackboard_R . Within the context of the majorization-minimization framework, the strategy to minimize Fğ¹Fitalic_F consists of two-steps. First, an auxiliary function G:ğ’´Ã—ğ’´â†’â„:ğºâ†’ğ’´ğ’´â„G\colon\mathcal{Y}\times\mathcal{Y}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_G : caligraphic_Y Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ blackboard_R with

for all Y,Yâ€²âˆˆğ’´ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œâ€²ğ’´Y,Y^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}italic_Y , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_Y is constructed. The majorizer GğºGitalic_G of Fğ¹Fitalic_F is then minimized in every iteration, that is,

Indeed, this procedure yields a non-increasing objective function value due to

Fâ¢(Y(n+1))â‰¤Gâ¢(Y(n+1),Y(n))â‰¤Gâ¢(Y(n),Y(n))=Fâ¢(Y(n)).ğ¹superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›1ğºsuperscriptğ‘Œğ‘›1superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›ğºsuperscriptğ‘Œğ‘›superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›ğ¹superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›F(Y^{(n+1)})\leq G(Y^{(n+1)},Y^{(n)})\leq G(Y^{(n)},Y^{(n)})=F(Y^{(n)}).italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_G ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_G ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

In the case of NMF with the KL divergence, the goal is to decompose Xâˆˆâ„+VÃ—Dğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘‰ğ·X\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{V\times D}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into the product of two non-negative matrices Wâˆˆâ„+VÃ—Kğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘‰ğ¾W\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{V\times K}italic_W âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V Ã— italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Hâˆˆâ„+KÃ—Dğ»superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ¾ğ·H\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{K\times D}italic_H âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by minimizing the reconstruction error

DKL(X||WH)=âˆ‘v,dxvâ¢dlogxvâ¢d(Wâ¢H)vâ¢dâˆ’xvâ¢d+(WH)vâ¢d.D_{\text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH)=\sum_{v,d}x_{vd}\log\frac{x_{vd}}{(WH)_{vd}}-x_{vd}+(% WH)_{vd}.italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Note that it is equivalent to minimize

F(W,H)=âˆ’âˆ‘v,dxvâ¢dlog(WH)vâ¢d+(WH)vâ¢d.F(W,H)=-\sum_{v,d}x_{vd}\log(WH)_{vd}+(WH)_{vd}.italic_F ( italic_W , italic_H ) = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

For simplicity, we will therefore often refer to DKLsubscriptğ·KLD_{\text{KL}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Fğ¹Fitalic_F interchangeably. An auxiliary function of DKLsubscriptğ·KLD_{\text{KL}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can now be constructed using the following two well-known results.

Lemma A.1 ([28, Lemma 3]).

Consider the function F(W,H)=âˆ’log(WH)vâ¢dF(W,H)=-\log(WH)_{vd}italic_F ( italic_W , italic_H ) = - roman_log ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for two indices v,dğ‘£ğ‘‘v,ditalic_v , italic_d. Then the function GğºGitalic_G defined by

Ï•vâ¢kâ¢dâ€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ï•â€²ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\displaystyle\phi^{\prime}_{vkd}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰”wvâ¢kâ€²â¢hkâ¢dâ€²(Wâ€²â¢Hâ€²)vâ¢d,â‰”absentsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤â€²ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptâ„â€²ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²superscriptğ»â€²ğ‘£ğ‘‘\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{w^{\prime}_{vk}h^{\prime}_{kd}}{(W^{\prime}H^{% \prime})_{vd}},â‰” divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

âˆ

Lemma A.2.

Corollary A.3 ([28, Lemma 3]).

Appendix B NMF with normalization constraints

In this section, we first proof 4.2, which states that global optima of NMF with a normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W (18) and NMF with a normalization constraint on both Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H (19) are identical up to a scaling of their topic weights by the total word counts âˆ‘vxvâ¢dsubscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘\sum_{v}x_{vd}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Second, we provide details to the derivation of the joint update rules of the two NMF problems with normalization constraints. Lastly, we show that the connection from 4.2 extends to iterates and fixed points of their MU algorithms.

Lemma 4.2.

Let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of NMF with a normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W (18) and let Î»d=âˆ‘vxvâ¢dsubscriptğœ†ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘\lambda_{d}=\sum_{v}x_{vd}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then (W,H~)ğ‘Š~ğ»(W,\widetilde{H})( italic_W , over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) with h~kâ¢d=hkâ¢d/Î»dsubscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘\widetilde{h}_{kd}=h_{kd}/\lambda_{d}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a solution of NMF with a normalization constraint on both Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H (19). Conversely, let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of (19). Then (W,H~)ğ‘Š~ğ»(W,\widetilde{H})( italic_W , over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) with h~kâ¢d=Î»dâ¢hkâ¢dsubscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\widetilde{h}_{kd}=\lambda_{d}h_{kd}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a solution of (18).

Proof.

The main ingredient of the proof is that solutions of NMF with the KL divergence (2) preserve the column sums of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X. That is, for any solution (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) of (2), we have

âˆ‘v(Wâ¢H)vâ¢d=âˆ‘vxvâ¢dsubscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘Šğ»ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘\sum_{v}(WH)_{vd}=\sum_{v}x_{vd}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (26)

[17, Theorem 6.9]. Now, let (W,H)ğ‘Šğ»(W,H)( italic_W , italic_H ) be a solution of NMF with an additional normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. Due to LemmaÂ 4.1, it is also a solution of the standard NMF problem (2). From (26) and wkâˆˆÎ”Vâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptÎ”ğ‘‰1w_{k}\in\Delta_{V-1}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it follows that âˆ‘khkâ¢d=âˆ‘vxvâ¢d=Î»d.subscriptğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘\sum_{k}h_{kd}=\sum_{v}x_{vd}=\lambda_{d}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Hence, the candidate solution (W,H~)ğ‘Š~ğ»(W,\widetilde{H})( italic_W , over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) defined via h~kâ¢d=hkâ¢d/Î»dsubscript~â„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘\widetilde{h}_{kd}=h_{kd}/\lambda_{d}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indeed fulfills the additional normalization constraint, and we also have

DKL(X||WH)=âˆ‘v,dxvâ¢dlogxvâ¢d(Wâ¢H)vâ¢d.D_{\text{KL}}(X\,||\,WH)=\sum_{v,d}x_{vd}\log\frac{x_{vd}}{(WH)_{vd}}.italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X | | italic_W italic_H ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_W italic_H ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG .

The result can now be shown using a standard proof by contraction. âˆ

âˆ‚hkâ¢dGâ¢((W,H),(W(n),H(n)))subscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğºğ‘Šğ»superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ»ğ‘›\displaystyle\partial_{h_{kd}}G((W,H),(W^{(n)},H^{(n)}))âˆ‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G ( ( italic_W , italic_H ) , ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) =âˆ’1hkâ¢dâ¢âˆ‘vxvâ¢dâ¢Ï•vâ¢kâ¢d(n)+âˆ‘vwvâ¢k.absent1subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜\displaystyle=-\frac{1}{h_{kd}}\sum_{v}x_{vd}\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}+\sum_{v}w_{vk}.= - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

which yields

wvâ¢kâˆâˆ‘dxvâ¢dâ¢Ï•vâ¢kâ¢d(n).proportional-tosubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›w_{vk}\propto\sum_{d}x_{vd}\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . hkâ¢dâˆâˆ‘vxvâ¢dâ¢Ï•vâ¢kâ¢d(n).proportional-tosubscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›h_{kd}\propto\sum_{v}x_{vd}\phi_{vkd}^{(n)}.italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Notice that the normalization in (29) just scales (28) by the total word counts âˆ‘vxvâ¢dsubscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘\sum_{v}x_{vd}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. More precisely, denoting the nğ‘›nitalic_n-th iterate of the NMF with a normalization constraint on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W AlgorithmÂ 4 by (W(n),NMF,H(n),NMF)superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›NMFsuperscriptğ»ğ‘›NMF(W^{(n),\text{NMF}},H^{(n),\text{NMF}})( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , NMF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , NMF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and the nğ‘›nitalic_n-th iterate of NMF with a normalization constraint on both Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W and Hğ»Hitalic_H / PLSA AlgorithmÂ 6 by (W(n),PLSA,H(n),PLSA)superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›PLSAsuperscriptğ»ğ‘›PLSA(W^{(n),\text{PLSA}},H^{(n),\text{PLSA}})( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , PLSA end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , PLSA end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we obtain the following result.

Lemma B.1.

Let Xâˆˆâ„+VÃ—Dğ‘‹subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‰ğ·X\in\mathbb{R}^{V\times D}_{+}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V Ã— italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and let Î»d=âˆ‘vxvâ¢dsubscriptğœ†ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£ğ‘‘\lambda_{d}=\sum_{v}x_{vd}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let W(0)âˆˆÎ”Vâˆ’1K,H(0)âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1Dformulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘Š0superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘‰1ğ¾superscriptğ»0superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ¾1ğ·W^{(0)}\in\Delta_{V-1}^{K},\,H^{(0)}\in\Delta_{K-1}^{D}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be normalized initial values. Then for all nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1italic_n â‰¥ 1

hkâ¢d(n),NMFsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›NMF\displaystyle h_{kd}^{(n),\text{NMF}}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , NMF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =Î»dâ¢hkâ¢d(n),PLSA,absentsubscriptğœ†ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘›PLSA\displaystyle=\lambda_{d}h_{kd}^{(n),\text{PLSA}},= italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , PLSA end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
